So, I had my first day of school on Wednesday. It was just as I remembered it: boring. I was ten minutes late to my 8 AM class (I had underestimated the time it'd take to get there in snow and morning rush hour traffic), and the teacher had already given an assignment: a 2-4 page in class paper due that day. Now, as much as I love writing (I don't), especially by hand (I really don't), this was annoying. It's the first day, read the syllabus, get to know us or whatever bs, and let us out. Fucking papers. My next class was a finance class, taught by the always entertaining Professor Singh. He has a thick accent, he's really boring, he's really bad at making people participate in class, and he grades on a curve, no matter what. So if the class average is a 95%, a person with a 95% will get a 2.7. Quick sidebar here about curves. Frankly, I think they're ridiculous. The point of school is to learn (in theory, anyway, which I'll get onto later). Now, to give people a passing, or even good, grade if they get less than 50% of credit in a class (yes, it does happen), is asinine. People can get a 4.0 without ever getting above 75% in any class, depending on teachers and classmates. Any employer who hires someone with a 4.0 will expect that person to know his shit, inside and out, not 75% of it. Should courses become easier, then, to eliminate the need for a curve? Nope, unless they become easier because the professors teach better and the students simply know more. I say fuck the curve. Throw it out the window. Sure, it'll mean most people currently in college won't be able to graduate. But it will lend a lot more weight to a degree. Employers will know who they're hiring will truly be of value. That, or have a universal curve accross the entire university, or at least accross different sections of classes. A 4.0 from one instructor does not necessarily demonstrate the same amount of knowledge as a 4.0 from another one. Now, if they do institute the no curve thing (which they never would but that's hardly the point!), colleges will become much fewer and far between. Most people won't be able to get into college. And that's how it should be. College, as it currently is, is bullshit. Almost everything you learn in college is thrown out the window the first day of your job. You have to learn entirely new and different things at your job, and they train you on the job even if you've been to college. So why even bother with college? Yes, for the undecided people, it does help in determining a career. But so could another year of high school and better counseling. Or, change college as it is. I don't need a writing class for accounting. I don't even need fucking math. Public speaking, history, social sciences, science? Nope. College could teach me everything I need to know to become an accountant in two years, max. But all those other classes just drag it out, are rather boring, and decrease my desire to go to school altogether. The day before this semester started, I thought of going back to school again, and the mere thought of it bored the hell out of me. I'm quite sick of it, I assure you. /sidebar So anyway, he goes on about the syllabus for awhile, then starts lecturing. He encouraged people to participate, got little to no response, but kept trying. You've got to respect that, eh? So anyway, he was talking about budgeting, differences in interest rates between loans, blah blah, and he asked the class "What's 4% of $15,000?" It seemed at first that he really didn't know, but I think he figured it out relatively quickly. I knew the answer before he finished answering the question, but I don't like answering things in class, unless called upon. Why? If I answer too often in class, people around me get it in their heads that I'm smart. So they ask me for help, ask me to tutor them, ask me to do their homework, all sorts of crap like that. If I help them out, they'll get a better grade. The curve encourages you to kill or be killed, so I prefer to not help people out to preserve my grade. Of course, if they ask, I'll help them no problem, but the key is to keep them from asking. So! After a long pause of people trying to figure it out, a guy in the back of the class says "$6,000." Yeah, that's right buddy, on a 4% loan of $15,000 you're going to pay $6,000 interest per year. Good one. Don't get me wrong here, I wouldn't be mad at the guy if he was called upon. But when you speak up of your own will with an answer, it means you're relatively certain of it. And that one was just...wrong. So I said the correct answer to get on with things because it is really frustrating listening to people. Ah, and in that class, some girl who on first glance seemed pretty cute sat next to me. She looked like a cross between Jeremiah's girlfriend (who everyone thinks is really cute) and Mrs. Robinson. Anyway, after looking at her at the end of class, I determined she wasn't all that cute. I did, however, give a cute girl directions early in the morn before my first class. ^_^ My last class of the day is public speaking. I was a couple minutes early to the class, but the teacher had already started. She quickly got on my nerves, with a very egotistic attitude. I knew right then that I wouldn't enjoy the class. Public speaking is not something I terribly enjoy, but I don't really mind it, either. I have my moments. But then, after about fifteen minutes of class, she dismissed us. What the fuck woman? I'm supposed to be despising you here, and you let me out not halfway through the class. I'm torn. so that was my first day. I have one other class on Monday, and I'll probably not talk about it in this journal, cause hey, I can only update so many times per year. Hopefully it'll be the best class ever. Wish me luck. ;p On a different, more fun topic, I've found myself enjoying some non-traditional gaming experiences. Last Thursday, we went to Conyell's pad and played some Karaoke Revolution. It was surprisingly fun, though I suck terribly at it. I'm sort of *gasp* thinking about purchasing it. If I thought my buds would play it with me, I would, but they're lame. Also, I played the EyeToy at Best Buy. While it does not recognize different parts of your body (you're supposed to head butt a ball in this soccer game, but you can use hands, shoulders, whatever) as it should, it's also kind of fun. And, of course, I purchased Ninja Assault for PS2, a light gun game. I only played it for about a minute, but I'm excited to usher in the days of light gun games on my PS2. I've always loved them, donchaknow. And Viewtiful Joe is simply...viewtiful. My New Year's Resolution: 1280x960

It's been awhile. Blackout 2003 has come and gone. What happened on this day? Well, I'll tell you a little tale. It was early afternoon the second day of my mini-nonvacation-vacation. Joe and I had planned to go to Flipside, Meijer's, and who knows where else? I arrived at Joe's house ready for a full day of shopping bliss only to find out that his watch had recently broken. No biggie, it's just a watch, right? Surely it cannot be a foreshadowing of what is to come? That would just be absurd! I inform Joe to bring his cell phone with him, as the Focus is unavailable and both the Taurus and the Escort are not the most reliable automobiles. I persisted, but he refused, saying the batteries were low. The battery power necessary to call home and say "THE CAR IS BROKEN COME PICK US UP KTHX" is rather low, I would say, so I didn't really mind. He continued to refuse and I let it go. Off we go in the Taurus. We arrive at Flipside, do some browsing, don't find anything great in particular. Flipside owner man offers us some sports games for the Xbox and we high-tail it out of there. Off we go in the Taurus again. ...or do we? No sir, as the Taurus has broken down. Without a cell phone on hand, we could not call home. We made our way around a very small section of downtown Clawson before finding a pay phone. Joe calls home, but only Sarah is there. She cannot drive, but she'll call up Jessica to pick us up. The directions Joe gave were a little shaky, which I didn't let him know until after he hung up. It was funny, what can I say? I enjoy a good laugh in the face of imminent death. So we go on a quest to get some change and use the pay phone again. This time we call Jessica directly, but no one answers. I call my sister and she gives us a ride back to Joe's. We grabbed his cell, then off we go in the Escort. A quick visit to Meijer's and my house, then off we head to another Meijer's. As we're driving southward, we hit a light that is not working. Scary stuff, as no one can handle that, especially not in nearly rush hour so I proceed cautiously. After another one passed, I decided to get off the road for a little bit to wait the power outage out. We see another light off as I head towards Hollywood Video. After a quick browse in the darkened store, I get bored and decide to brave the road, at least to Joe's. I decided to take a different route this time, as hopefully Rochester Road would be all right. Turning on Newsradio 950, however, I found out that this was not the case. Massive blackout blah blah, you know the story. My mind quickly flashes to my friends and family, hoping they're safe. Luckily, I knew Joe was, as he was with me, and Porath would be, as he was working. Plus I knew my sister and mom were snugly in my house, so that was cool. After two miles, the Escort refuses to break the 30 MPH barrier and I decided to let it rest briefly as I thought it was overheating. After a five minute or so rest, we head out again. It's doing all right for a little bit, but then craps out again. I went through Kyle's sub as the speed limit was low enough that the 30 MPH driving wouldn't be dangerous. Halfway through the sub, we smell burning and decide it best to stop driving and walk the rest of the way home. About this time, after Joe's lost his watch and didn't bring his cell phone, along with both of our cars breaking down and the continent-wide power outage, it is beginning to look like the end of the world. All because Joe wouldn't buy Diddy Kong Racing. We're a mile, a mile and a half from Joe's and he doesn't know how to get home. I'm not sure the quickest way to do so, exactly, but I take my chances. The quickest way, it turns out, was through a small forest. I encouraged Joe to pick up a large stick to defend himself with, while I would use my bare hands, as a monk should. So we take a nice nature trail, then do a river crossing exercise on some rocks and get back into Joe's sub. Shortly after, we're at Joe's house, chilling with his family. There is very little to do without electricity. I called my house to let my parents know I was okay, but no one answered. Probably busy readying the guns. We called Porath's as well to make sure he made it home safe, but no one answered there either. Twas slightly distressing. To relieve our nerves, we decided to play some Monopoly. One game was had in daylight, the second by candlelight. Candlelight is not the best in terms of lighting up a Monopoly board. Sleep was had and enjoyed by all. The next day, power was restored and life began to get back to normal. So that was my blackout 2003 experience. Much fun. Fast forward to this week. Jeannine was supposed to have a BBQ on Friday. It has since been canceled, but I will tell the story regardless. I asked Rom to switch his Saturday 9-5 with my Friday 6-C over the phone. He agreed without much question. The next day: "So why is it that we switched?" "I've got a BBQ to go to." "You've gotta be kidding me." "Nope." "It's a family BBQ or something, right? Like a family reunion." "Nope." "Whose is it?" "Jeannine." "Who is that?" "She works at 18/Rochester." "She does? Is she a manager?" "Yeah, she's an opener." "The small girl that was here earlier today?" "Yeah, that's her." "She's cute." "Yep." "Okay, switching is fine." Oh that Romuald. Only saying switching is fine because Jeannine's cute. Silly man. I told Lisa about the BBQ today and this was the conversation: "Why wasn't I invited?" "Actually, Jeannine said specifically to keep you from coming." "What! She doesn't even know me!" "Sure she does, she works at 18 and Rochester." "Is she your girlfriend?" At which point I smile, as I KNEW Lisa was going to ask that and reply "Nope." "She must be your girlfriend, you're lauhging!" "Yep. That's it Lisa. Only guys with girlfriends can laugh." I hate not knowing.

Okay, so I'm in this Basic Shift Management Class, I believe I mentioned it earlier. Today, we went to observe a restaurant in action, and try to see what went wrong and why. Here is the tale: OMG do not eat at the McDonald's at 8 mile road and Lahser. Unless, of course, dying or getting a foodborne illness is high on your priorities list. Using expired food and touching uncooked meat with the same gloves as uncooked chicken products and cooked food being the two biggest food safety issues, but there were more. So many more. Like going to the bathroom wearing an apron, then going back to work with the same apron on. I just...damn. And we had to eat there. She wouldn't let us leave and go somewhere else for food. She also wouldn't let me cook my own food :(. I should have foregone eating, but I was pretty hungry and am not afraid to die or anything. If I do die, however, someone please sue the hell out of them in my name. Thank you very much. I mean, food safety wasn't the only thing about the store that was bad, but customers can't see the horrible food safety issues, as their grills and fryers were behind a wall. But of the things that did matter, well, the food did taste pretty good, so they had that one thing working for them. However, the crew members and the managers were rude to customers. Not only that, but service times were horrendously slow. Now, the times at my store are pretty bad. Our average DT time is over a minute over what it should be and our counter times aren't the best. But these times were far worse. A group of the people with us got in the counter line, which had about 10 people in it, including the two people in the group. From the time they got in the line until the first person in this group took her order, it was about 15 minutes. There was a counter runner, so the counter person only had to worry about taking orders. How the fuck is it going to take you about 15 minutes just to take the orders of 8 people? Do you realize that's almost 2 minutes per person? Do you understand English? Do you realize you're a fucking manager? Do you know how much I just wanted to slap you? Another thing about counter. So you've got ten people in the store. That means you have people on these stations, in this order: 1) Counter, 2) Back Cash (DT order taker), 3) Meat person, 4) Initiator (Sandwich maker), 5) DT Presenter (hands out food), 6) Assembler (finishes the sandwiches), 7 ) Fry person, 8) Counter runner (gets orders together for counter customers, hands them out), 9) Initiator, side two (we have two sides of the sandwich making table, so when we get busy, we put someone on the second side, a certain 9th someone), 10) DT runner. They also had two shift managers (people who aren't supposed to make food, but are supposed to supervise, provide encouragement, and help out only if it gets really busy and service is suffering). Now, say your fry person has to go to the bathroom. What do you do? Do you tell your 10th person to make fries, and act like you only have 9 people for that time? Do you, as the manager, cover the fry station for a couple of minutes until that person comes back? Do you have the 10th person make fries while you cover running for DT for that time? All three of those are acceptable, and I'd do the first, most likely. We'll play a little game and see what they chose. You have those three suggestions or you could choose other. Now, what do you think that they did? I'll give you some time to think about it. Go ahead, try to ponder what they did in the situation. Giving you some more time. Thought of something yet? Okay, I'll let you know what they did. The 8th person went on fries, while the 9th and 10th people stayed where they were. "Gee, while this isn't something I would do, it isn't such a problem.
